newsitem.title: SWEDEN: SSAB sees '96 profits sharply down.
newsitem.headline: SSAB sees '96 profits sharply down.

text.p: Swedish steel producer SSAB posted on Thursday a higher than expected profit for the first half of the year, but said it expected profits for the year to be halved on 1995 levels.

Although the steelmaker's profit after financial net of 1.49 billion crowns for the first half was the second best ever for that period, it was still a 35 percent fall on the 2.29 billion crowns reported for the first half of 1995.

Even so, the figure was slightly better than market expectations of a 1.42 billion crown profit after financial net, and the share gained 1.50 crowns in Stockholm to 84.50 immediately after the results were published.
Falling steel prices bore some of the blame for the earnings tumble, SSAB said in a statement.
"Steel prices have fallen by more than 20 percent in the space of three quarters. Against that background, the result was strong," SSAB president Leif Gustafsson said.

Of the 800 million crown fall in profits, some 600 million was due to lower margins in the steel operation, and a stronger Swedish crown -- the bane of Swedish exporters during the first half of the year -- accounted for 250 million.

Operating income for the period declined to 9.41 billion crowns from 9.99 billion in the first half of last year, and higher costs and depreciation resulted in a 40 percent drop in operating profit to 1.28 billion crowns.
Falling steel consumption in combination with shorter delivery times and de-stocking on the part of customers had resulted in weak order intake for the Western European steel industry, SSAB said.
This had resulted in falling prices for most products over the first two quarters, and SSAB said the group's steel prices had fallen by five percent in the second quarter.

"We are meeting the downturn in the steel cycle with a continued focus on our niche products ... strip and quenched steel in the heavy plate area and by cost-cutting throughout the company," Gustafsson said.

SSAB said it would invest a total of 350 million crowns in improving the production flow in its heavy plate operations and the contruction of a special line for thin hardened plate at its Swedish Oxelosund mill.
Even so, prospects for the rest of the year were gloomy, Gustafsson said.

"In all, the current development of steel prices and currency exchange rates in combination with the traditionally weak third quarter is expected to lead a result after financial items about half that of last year's record of 3.83 billion crowns," he said.
